												So, I"ve got lots of very expensive big budget games in my little library. This little indie game is much better, and played far more often then many of them. It puts you in command of a little squad of ships, one of which you control directly. You hop around from system to system doing jobs for factions and trying to upgrade you ships. The ships are very configurable, and there are quite a few of them to play around with. All of this is very addictive. I've blinked and realised a couple of hours have flown by while I've been hopping accross the galaxy looking for that next level reactor part, or missle launcher, or new hull. The size of the galaxy is configured at the start of the game, and a huge galaxy is really huge. Looking back at that statement, it sounds funny, but it's true :). If you find the whole zombie craze very tired (like myself), don't be put off by the fact that it's in the title of this game. The zombies aren't really a "more brains" kind of thing, but more like the reavers in the movie Serenity.I've gotten a lot of value out of this game. I really don't think you can go wrong if you decide to pick it up. Oh, and they're working on spaz 2 right now. Yay :).

												I'm enjoying the heck out of this game. It's top-down 2D space combat primarily, with some exploration and slight RPG-ish aspects. The game features pretty good AI, has lots of outstanding ship customization options, a fun story, and it's got a pretty small hard drive footprint. SPAZ can get somewhat repetitive if you generate a large galaxy to explore, but a big galaxy also allows you plenty of areas to grind for levels or items to beat down a story mission or particular system. I've had a great time setting up my fleet for different play styles, such as all cargo/mining, area exploration, stealth, and having many many different enemy abuse options. There's a whole lot of trade-off going on with more advanced items not necessarily being automatically better in all circumstances, which I like very much. On top of all this goodness, there are zombies. Space zombies. So love/hate toward them. Check SPAZ out, it's a good one!

												SPAZ is yet another game that the screenshots and trailers do no justice. The game was made by only two people.The universe you are set in is randomly generated and has a small amount of customization in size. The smaller the universe, the harder the difficulty between each galaxy. The bigger the universe, the longer the overall game and the more stretched out resources are. The game tells you not to do your first playthrough on the hardest difficulty. I immediately went and ignored this because I love a good challenge.And boy does SPAZ deliver. You have up to three of your own ships in play at once. You can manually control one of the three ships at any time and the AI will take over the other two. The combat can go beyond mindlessly killing at times in the harder difficulties and thought is needed to plan out what you are going to do. Getting a game over is rare but progression is also challenging.Good for casual and hardcore players. I'd write more but I've run out of room.

												Great game. Top down two dimensional view arcade-y space sim-lite. A mouthful! Side with the UTA (the established military forces) or the civilians of countless star systems while keeping safe from zombies and bounty hunters in your quest to the core of the universe. Power up your ships, find blueprints and build new ones, customize them with a variety of weapons and systems, or maybe just mine asteroids until your eyes bleed. 												This is one of my favorite indie games on Steam - a true gem. Even though it's made by a two-man team, this is an awesome 2D space combat game. It's not laden with overly complicated interfaces and rule systems like a lot of strategy games, yet has enough customizability and complexity to keep the player engaged. Ignore the story, and focus on configuring your ships. My 40 hours on a single playthrough is proof of how much fun I had. Some may find the combat repetitive eventually, but I found the steady trickle of new weapons enough to keep me invested. I love this game and am very excited for the sequel!

												I ended up putting in way more hours than I ever thought I would in playing this game. All in good fun, though. It's a good top down space shooter with a lot to do, some quirky humor, and several different ways of playing (though maybe only a few work best in Insane difficulty -- canons and stealth are your friend until you build up the tech to face things head on). It can be a bit grindy at times, especially when you get to the Zombies part of the title, as you'll want to acquire powerful tech and ship blueprints to deal with them (and this goes double especially on Insane difficulty). But, if you get into it, you'll barely notice all the time pass until you've suddenly put in over 100 hours. A good, well-put together game at a cheap price. Worth the full price. A no brainer when on sale. :)

												I've been hooked on this for a while, it's easy to pick up and play with just enough complexity to keep you going. I find myself in that "one more turn" mentality. It's an upgrade-based game, and that does mean a bit of grind, which may seem like a dirty word to use, but it is the sort of 'waves of enemies' and 'perfect your game' kind of deal. It definitely doesn't feel like a chore, and stays fun and addictive.Big applause to the devs for breaking up gameplay style in how the chapters work. This mechanic kept the gameplay fresh and exciting!

er 4, 2013
												Space Pirates and Zmbies is a top down space shoot em up. Having not completed anything other than easy or medium, try not taking this review into account for the harder difficulty settings.The game itself starts off slow when you are given the worst of the worst ships named the Short Bus. This thing's beam cannot kill pretty much anything. But new and better ships start coming along very soon with the player going from the worst laser ever to lasers and cannons. (For the cannon think of a rifle in those games where you can hold down the trigger or whatever, where it shoots at a moderate speed.)Even though the guns get better some poeple may still think of them as utter crap as the better stuff comes in much later.Also new players may find the shooting with both lasers and cannons very frustrating and have the A.I do most of the work.The game also features 3 resources. rez, goons and data.  Rez a brightly coloured space rock that doubles as the currency of the game  as well as the raw resource that you build your ships with. The game does a very good job of allowing you to collect rez and not loose it. The enemy ships, you will be fighting, nearly always drop a nice chunk of rez for you to loot whereas your ships deposit your supllies of rez into a large pool that you (mostly) cannot lose.The next resource is goons. Goons are workers/slaves/mercenaries that you pick up in escape pods floating around in space. Picking them up ads them to your goon pool much like your rez pool. Unlike rez, goons are used to keep your ship in tip top shape once it is flying, rather then build it. The amount of goons that join you when you pick them up depends on your crew skill.Your crew skill is an indication of how well you keep oder/how much they like you. At first this skill will be very low, level zero in fact. At this low level most of the crew get thrown out of the air lock of your ships instead of being crewed. This could be a bit frustrating as 6 crew can suddenly turn into 3 crew as half are chucked out the air lock for being troble makers.But there is usally so many crew pods, you rarely have this problem.Then there's the last resource data. Data are little bits of trashed computer parts and what not, scattered about the place after you trash a bunch of your foes. Data is unique in the fact that it can generate itself as well as goons.  Every time you collect a certain amount of data, starting at about 100 (eazy to do as you collect it in tens at a time) you clone a certain amount of your current goons into new ones.Data also allows you to progress along a tech tree of sorts as each time you level up you gain 3 points to spend. The points can be spent in things such as shields thrusters or drones. Each certain amount of points you put into a certain category upgrades it a bit. And with the best weapons upgraded to the full level (10) or even a little below it (8) you can blast and melt your way through whatever even looks at you funny without a care.Next up(ALERT! ALERT! SPOILERS INCOMING!) Zombies. Zombies come into the game at a very late point which is a bit weird considering the game is called space pirates and zombies. They can be a bit of a pain if faced without the right equipment, for example without a point defence system (a little red cricle that shoots a red laser at incoming zombies and missiles) they can swarm your ship, take down its sheilds, kill its crew and infect it, turning what was once your best ship, against you. Another slightly annoying thing they do, is spawn the very tiny ships called ticks that, once injured enough, will fly faster then you can to the edge of the screen causing you to retreat back to your mother ship and then warp to a new place, rather than just warping, as you cannot warp when there are enemies nearby.2nd last on this reveiw is bounty hunters. Bounty hunters can be a HUGE pain in the backside as they track whoever you kill, causing your bounty to rack up. Once this bounty is high enough it will cause the bounty hunters to come after you for that sweet bounty on your head. If not prepared properly these guys can wreck you and your ships pretty fast. That's why I recommend for any new players to turn them down to low in the starting settings. This will make sure you are not getting smoked by them every time you warp to a new sector, but also allow you to find out what they are like and how they work.Lastly are space stations. Space stations are big shielded things that stay in one place. But be careful who you anger in this game. As flying to a space station, when either it is to high a level for you or you are to low a level for it, can leave you with no rez or ships if it blows them all up. Also a tip for a mid level mission, in which I got stuck on for a while, where you have to shoot a space station untill it gives up its reactor for you. My tip is if you can't beat it at first just grind a bit of low level stuff first. Trust me, at first it may be boring but it defenitly is worth it when you beat the station and move on to the better parts of the game.Well, that just about wraps up this review and my few last words are: A good game for most poeple, but better if you're patient and don't mind a bit of a grind.

r 3, 2014
												Simply fantastic. If you are looking for a good old 2D space adventure game where you can: a) Unlock many different ships, weapons and components, b) Upgrade various aspects of your ships, c) Be a pirate and prey on civilian ships, d) Bribe officials and manipulate relations with the police or the civilians, e) Use a massive battleship to blast a starbase to pieces and collect the loot because you didn't want to pay them for it, f) Participate in bounty hunter battle events and win their respect, g) Use this respect to order the bounty hunters to attack a warp gate blockade for you, h) Fight zombies, i) Battle squads of enemy ships and blow them to bits, and pick up the jettisoned crew to join your ranks, j) Rampage through the galaxy and cause general chaos in each individual solar system... then you should buy this game.The devs said that they created SPAZ because they couldn't find games like it anymore. This is sadly true, but now you can play this game so it's all okay. It is not the most fast-paced or the most action-packed game (although big battles are quite exciting) but it doesn't try to be. It is just a completely amazing space adventure that lets you choose where to go next and what to do when you get there.You are let loose in a galaxy that you design (for the most part), and you are free to explore solar systems, mess around with politics, and level yourself up so you can venture into harder areas. To get to a new system you have to either destroy the UTA (police) warp gate blockade, bribe them with goons, or use bounty hunters to clear the blockade for you. You can then continue to the next system, and because there is no communication between systems, the people there will have no clue what you have been up to. In each system there are small, basic missions that you can do, and occasionally a conflict pops up between the two sides, which you can join in.There IS a storyline, which is quite intriguing, but the story missions are relatively few and quickly jump to much harder areas. You have to explore and level up before continuing on, but you can do the story whenever you really want, or if you get bored of exploring all the other solar systems, because they are mostly the same, and when you have acquired all of the blueprints that you get from lower-level systems, there is not really much need to go all the way around the galaxy. But it's still fun to go to every place, especially if you are someone who loves exploration.There are lots of ships of varying sizes and all of them are designed for a different purpose. You can easily change between ship designs and equip different weapons and support modules. Later on in the story you get more hangars, which means more ships. You can only control one at a time but you can freely swap between them, and the AI controls the others. You can give orders to your AI-controlled ships, although they can be pretty frustratingly stupid sometimes. Especially when armed with huge bombs, because they fire them off everywhere as soon as they reload, usually causing high damage to you or friendly ships, which quickly turn hostile.Combat ranges from not-all-that-interesting with smaller ships, to exciting, lasers-and-giant-explosions when several large ships are pitted against each other. Many small details have been perfected in this game, some of which are: shockwaves from exploding ships will damage anything that is too close, and firing on one side of a ship will wear down the armour and allow you to deal more damage, as well as causing minerals and crew members to be sucked out into space through breaches in the hull.Yes, there are zombies in this game. They are found in the central solar systems. They are very annoying (they have a tendency to split and create more, and there are lots of them) and can be dangerous and head to deal with if you are not careful. Luckily, both the Civs and the UTA hate the zombies as well, and there are often conflicts between zombies and one or both of them.The graphics are nice, the backgrounds are nice, the ships all look nice, the explosions are nice, sound effects are nice, everything I have mentioned previously in this review is nice. You might not like this type of game and that's fine, but if you are remotely interested in the concept then you should definitely buy it. The price is overly reasonable, especially on sale. Recommended.

ry 27, 2014
												SPAZ is one of my top 3 games, only second to Borderlands 2. Don't let its silly name and kinda weird storyline decieve you. SPAZ's simple 2D top down style and insane amount of customization will keep you entertained for months. Installing a mod is easy, and creating your own is just as easy but even more satisfying, because even the smallest changes can completely change gameplay style giving it an amazing replay factor. Aside from the gameplay, the dialogue is hilarious, and side story missions are very rewarding when it comes to stat bonuses. Speaking of stat bonuses, SPAZ's uniquely simple research system can make all the difference in life and death situations. If I could change any one thing about this game, I would make it more popular. Why? Because the TWO developers (yes, ONLY TWO PEOPLE MADE THIS!) deserve more credit and support than they are currently getting. Fore what it's worth, on a scale of one to ten, I give this a nine.

content:
9, 2013
												The first thing you'll notice about SPAZ is the customization.  Do you want to play in a massive galaxy?  Do you want to be starved for technology?  Do you want to turn off the Bounty Hunters entirely?  You can do that.  The customization of course applies to the many different ship types, such as what armament to use and even the level-up system, so maybe you want to focus on shields first or maybe you like the punch of cannons so you focus on those.  SPAZ is not an RTS, but it has some elements, like having resources to manage (albeit it's just REZ for money and Goons for slave labor), which you use for the production of your up to four ships for your small fleet, and both are used for the purchase of new weapons blueprints.  You also have to maintain relations between you and two factions, or three with the included And Bounty Hunters expansion.  Do you fight the UTA for the benefit of the CIVs, or do you backstab both groups for your own profit?  This is complicated by the fact that every sector has its own faction relation to you, and anything you do in one sector has no effect on the rest.  But that's where the Bounty Hunters come in.  There are light RPG elements too, mainly in how you spend your upgrade points in what trees to bolster your ships and enable the use of better equipment.  There is a good variety of missions, like destroy X many crates without being seen, or destroying a big ice meteor before it plows through a research station, or the simple "kill everyone of this faction" and everything rewards you with money, people, and typically a change in faction relation.  Or maybe some new equipment, or even a little bit of story.  The game changes pretty drastically during the final chapter, though you are given advance warning before this point.  And you don't even have to do missions all the time.  You can just pop by the mining colony and chip away at meteors for money...only for one of the groups you ticked off to suddenly warp in and you're now scrambling to send away your mining ships for battle ones.  There's a good bit of stuff to do and collect and kill in this game.  I especially like the fact that you can custom-tailor your experience to start, though there's no way to change that once you've started.  Battles are oftentimes difficult and relying on your AI allies is an exercise in frustration, but learning the nuances of the weapons and how much impact the different gear you can equip to every ship is essential for victory.  Do you want a massive battlecruiser with extremely strong shields and armor?  Or maybe a tiny ship with extreme speed for hit-and-run tactics?  Why not both?  You can only directly control one ship at a time, but the ability to swap at any time might be essential to keep everyone alive and to keep your coffers full.And this game has no discrete "game over" condition, as you can always fight back from zero even in the final chapter, though it will be tedious and difficult to rebuild your fleet when you've no REZ nor Goons.  And while you're slowly chipping away at stray rocks in the Short Bus after a massive defeat, you'll be thinking up a plan to exact your revenge.  It will be glorious.  So yeah.  SPAZ is a game I like.

												This is a great game. If you know Star control 2 then this is basically a tribute to that, but then with an ARPG twist. It's a bit like Diablo in space. You can explore a very attractive looking 2d universe and shoot lots of interesting and increasingly powerful spaceships and then you can build them yourself and customize them with weapons and upgrades.The story has some interesting twists to keep it fresh and you will feel a great sense of progression. In a nutshell, this game is awesome. It was developed by a small indie company so it is sometimes a bit rough around the edges but the gameplay is very solid and if you like space shooters with progression then this should keep you busy for many, many hours. I highly recommend it.

content:
19, 2012
												I picked this up in the winter sale and I quite enjoy it. I remember playing a game called Star Control when I was a kid and SPAZ seems very keen to evoke those memories.The bulk of the game is spent carrying out missions (i.e. quests) which will reward currency and/or reputation with each system's faction. Speaking of which, each system has two sides: UTA (Empire) and Civilians (Rebels). You don't always have to butter up one or the other, and which side you'll have to ♥♥♥♥ off will vary from system to system. It's very much up to you how and where you want to go questing, but the levelling process can feel a bit grindy.The combat is fun but not overly deep, and things can get a bit repetitive. I've put 30 hours into it so far and I've only really just got into the meat of the campaign I think. At a sale price, I'd say it's worth it. I wouldn't be disappointed to buy it at 50% off so anything else is a bonus.p.s. If you're on the fence, TRY THE DEMO. It's a good taster.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 15, 2014
												I'd seen SPAZ go on sale a few times but never really paid much attention until it went on sale for $2 and I had a spare bit of change in my Steam wallet.Best $2 that I've ever spent, unless you could the 3 sausage rolls for a pound (about 2 dollars more or less) from Greg's bakery.I am a huge fan of Star Control and never thought that any game could live up to the standard that it set way back in the days of the Sega Megadrive. I was wrong. Whether it was inspired by SC or not, I don't know, but if you liked SC and want a modernized version of it, SPAZ is the best that there is.If you haven't played Star Control, I will give you the gist of what SPAZ is. Spaz is a top down space shooter. You are in command of a band of Space pirates. With humble beginnings, you can gradually work your way up and become more powerful, reverse engineering ships that you destroy, gathering resources to build researched ships and to buy blueprints for new modules to go on them. You can fly into combat with a small fleet of AI controlled allies, toggling between the ships at will to command for yourself.If you like games with depth and action and don't care about graphics, I fully recommend this game. I got it for a bargain, but even it's full price is well worth the expense. A must have.

content:
4, 2015
												I normally never both to review games on Steam, but in this case I'll make an exception. Maybe this game is a type of genre people enjoy that just isn't for me and that's fine, but the reason I can't recommend it is about 50% of the game could be flat out cut. I've had this game in my Library for a long time and wanted to finish it as I'm a bit of a completionist. However, upon returning to it recently I cannot bring myself to play it anymore. There seems so much to this game and based on what I saw before buying it I was excited to customize my ships and all that jazz but 6.8 hours into the game what have I actually accomplished? Very little. Sure, I could be accused of not being patient or wanting maximum rewards for minimum effort, but in most other games during that time I'd have done more than float about a few quadrents listening to the same dam messages repeat over and over and over. Warp to a place, kill some guys, rinse and repeat. There might be more to this game later but so far I've had so little fun I can't bare to get further. I guess if you really want to find a way to sink hundereds of hours into floating about doing repetitive tasks in the most unfun way possible this is the game for you.

content:
y 16, 2014
												This quirky little game is great because you can pick it up any time you have an extra 20 mins to kill and want to have some fun.  The biggest detraction is that I find the gameplay a little grinding. To advance between systems you have to be about equivalent or better than the technology level of your enemy. This means you often find yourself grinding to get your tech level up, respec your ships, and then go blast away the bad guys. If you fail to do this you find yourself quickly decimated by an AI who has superior firepower. While I may not have the finer points of ship selection and counter measures figured out, I think this is a fair assesment of the gameplay. Despite this flaw, its still fun to shoot lasers at brightly colored ships until they disenegrate into start dust...and then zap their crew members as they writhe around helplessly in space.

y 4, 2013
												This game is a very interesting type I've never really tried in the past. It's based on this group who end up having their main station destroyed and reduced to the lowest tech and losing all tech, but you manage to have some to make ships and continue to claim blueprints through the game.As the titles suggest it's in space and you fight against Pirates and Zombies as wll as military and civilian. You can either do jobs for either sides to gain Rez (currency) to buy schematics for new ships or weapons. You can also gain tech points for research into using better weapons, shields and armour.It's certainly a very long game with a lot of grind, but you don't have to buy stuff from space stations as if you are well enough equipped you can destroy their station and steal all they have for free, but it only depends on the balance between how many times you've died and what you get out of it as the payment for making your ship can be very big if you spent a lot of money to make your Ship massive.

												I did not find the combat enjoyable one tiny bit.  The ship handling is sloppy.  The ships have tons of momentum and terrible acceleration so changing directions is a pain and takes way too long.  You spend most of your time flying past your enemies and missing your shots, then trying to turn around for another pass, only to miss again, and then turn around again, and so on and so forth.  Actually killing anything took way too long and was simply more trouble and aggravation than it was worth.  I was mislead by an idiotic comment by a curator, describing the game as "arcadey", it's anything but.  Do not expect to get your space combat thrills here.

content:
ry 4, 2012
												So far I'd say I have spent more time in the hangar costumizing my fleet and trying to figure out the best trade offs to be made than actually blowing up enemy ships. This game has a very decent variety of weapons, sub systems, mounts, armors, shields, engines and all that good stuff you can apply to your ships in order to costumize them. Ships of all classes and sizes are available (fighters, support ships, battleships, mining ships, mass bomb carriers), you just have to unlock them by a very simple unlock system (blow up the ship you want and collect its black box from the remains). The battles are fun and actually require you to maneuver your ship around in a strategic fashion in order to get the best from your beams, cannons, turrets...and also to avoid enemy fire. For a 2 man work, this game is a blast.

content:
6, 2016
												I played this all the way through (offline) back in the day. It's strange because the shallow gameplay would normally cause me to give it a thumbs down, but there is something about this game that got me totally hooked and I've recently played it halfway through again. Now that I've come here to write a review I've discovered that SPAZ2 has just gone to early access and the video for it it making my heart thump already. Anyway, back to my review...Cons (none of which matter to me)The game universe is enormous but to be honest all a bit samey. You have to complete endless tasks to gain the technology and resources to upgrade your ships, but these tasks mostly involve battling enemies which is really the be-all and end-all of this game. In theory you're supposed to tailor your ships/weapons to the task at hand, but in practice it doesn't really seem to matter, you just equip the best weapons you can find and use them for everything. It's not the most intellectually challenging game.Con (which does matter)There is a storyline to this game, with an ending. After it had finished, to my dismay, I discovered that it was impossible to go back and play some more with the massive battleships I had worked for hours on end to build up. Bear this in mind before you tackle the final task, or make a data backup!ProsIt's all about building bigger and better ships with more and more firepower and watching the battle mayhem. Especially towards the end of the game when huge battleships are blasting each other to smithereens it's a sight to behold, and the amazing thing is that all this glorious graphics action doesn't seem to lag or stutter at all, it's smooth as silk.Now enough of this, I'm off to buy SPAZ2!

content:
ber 3, 2011
												This is very reminiscent of older space exploration games I used to play (whose names I can't remember which is why I picked this up on a whim). You start off piloting a flying trash can and through the tutorial fix it up enough to control a small fleet. There is some seriously deep customization with your ships. With carriers that can support their own miniature fleets to turret covered behemoths that can shoot 360°, both the pea-shooters you get at the beginning and the imperial destroyers you get near the end all have their uses throughout the whole game. There are some balancing issues with weapons (cannons are a swiss-army knife that destroy everything while missiles are useless late game because of point blank defense systems, etc.) and framerate slowdown once the zombies joins the fray, but patches are being worked on to fix these issues and add more content.If you enjoy 4X games, this $15 variation is worth your money just for the nostalgia rush.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2016
												This won't be a review that shows all the facts, the pros and cons. It's rather going to be my personal love letter for this game. I picked up Space Pirates and Zombies a few years ago, not long after the release. Since then it really found a straight way into my gamer heart, making me play it again every few months. I can say without doubt, that this game is among my Top 3 favourite games of all time!Who didn't want to fly around in big space ship discovering the universe when they were young? SPAZ made this dream come true for me... at least on the screen. It is the perfect mix of flying around, discovering, building up your small fleet, fancy and colourful explosions, tactics, ship management, looting and a simple but funny told story, which matches the title. There's always this next blueprint you wanna get in order to upgrade you ships. There's always this next planet or galaxy you wanna visit to find out what treasures it withholds from you. There's always this next mission you want to complete, this next ship you want to destroy, this next achievement you want to achieve. And just like this hours passed by and I experienced how evenings turned into nights turned into mornings, until I was finally too tired to continue with the adventure of my small space fleet.In the end I highly recommend this game to everybody felt a little of the joy and excitement while reading this. Even if you won't get as much out of it as I did, I can still pretty much promise you quite some hours of fun. And if this game is on sale, it really is a must buy!

content:
ber 21, 2014
												Frustrating, tedious, hard.  Sometimes SPAZ makes me want to eat my keyboard at times.Yet I come back to it.  Why?  Why?  Why?Update: The frustration outweighed the fun, finally.  I stopped coming back to this game.  Too grindy later in the game.Actually, I know why.  The game doesn't have the most balanced mechanics, nor does the difficulty ramp up all that smoothly (more like, brick-walls on you if you aren't careful).  But it's a 2D space combat simulator with a teeny little bit of RPG tossed in for good measure and a heavy exploration element, and by God's Bones, they dun make games like this no more.There's lots of ships to unlock and lots of goodies to toss onto said ships, so at least if you feel bored using one sort of build you can swap it for another.If you put in lots of hours in games like StarControl, Escape Velocity: Nova, StarFlight and Solar Winds, then buy SPAZ and enjoy it.  If you have no idea what any of those games are, then you might want to pass.  Then again, it's on sale at times for just a few bucks, so what do you have to lose?  Aside from a few bucks.Pros:* Nobody makes these kinds of games anymore, OH WAIT, they did!* Lots of ships and weapons/upgrades to discover.* Big universe to explore.* Nice visuals and sound effects.Cons:* Big universe to explore.  Becomes tedious after a while since systems must be unlocked one at a time.* Chunky and slow during big space battles, especially later in the game with lots of ______'s flying about spewing chunks.  (*Spoilers!)* Space battles can end up near-stalemate battles of attrition, which take a long time to resolve.* Less story-telling versus games like EV:Nova, etc.

content:
, 2016
												Fun simple space game. Control 2-4 ships of different sizes which you can customize a little (i.e. choose weapons and features according to specific spots). Each system basically has an oppressive government group and rebellious civilian group. They’re relationship with you depends on the system and your actions. You may enter one system where the government loves you and the civilians hate you, then move into the next system where the gov. hates you and the civies love you, then the next system they both love you. You actions in one system does not affect the others. The missions in each system will affect your relationships in that system so be careful. Unique game, fun to play. Pros-	Each game is randomly generated so your experiences will always be different.-	Simple to learn/playCons-	The story doesn’t necessarily enthrall you but its there.

												Earlier it came to my attention that none of my friends own this game, so I am here to inform. Space Pirates and Zombies is an open-world, 2D space-themed shooter and everyone should buy this game. Not only is it amazing that a team of two created this, but they did a really good job on it. They did a better job than some large game corporations have done on games before. Amazing combat, soo much to do, hilarious dialogues, really cool story, and you have ultimate control of how you get to point B. You can power your way through, or take your time and get everything one step at a time, just depends how you like to play. This game is for all styles of gamer and you should get it! (The intro screen made me type that D:)

												I HATE HATE      HATE HATEHATE          Trying to learn new complex games that are a really great but it's fun.  What I mean is that I just learned how to play Project Zomboid(coincidence, not on a zombie kick), FTL and a couple others and I wanna know how to play instantly because my brain is about to explode.   I Just got the basics down on this and got through my first gate and did a couple side missions and can tell this is gonna be a great one(game that is) and I'm going to compare it to FTL and hope to not get yelled at and because I just wanna say that it's kinda like FTL but much more better because graphix and seems to be deeper in stuff and mechanics and well everything.   9.5/10 so far.  I guess -.5 for the tutorial skipping on a few much needed pointers/tips. I highly recommend reading and/or watching some tutorials.    There is one on youtube that I watched where a dude plays through the beginning but doesn't do a great job explaining what each thing is so it's probably best to find other info out or play the demo and then watch his vid like I did   Yeah, I did the demo for an hour and kinda kept it in the back of my head that dying was ok because it wasn't the real game yet, so this may be a good strategy for others. Also S.P.A.Z. 2 is coming out soon I think and hoping I get enough play in here to help me there.    Hope this helps and that the "and's" were a bit humorous and not annoying(eek...)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2016
												Space Pirates and Zombies (SPAZ) is a top-down, 2D space pirate combat game where you explore the galaxy completing quests, finding resources, and upgrading your ships.  There is a story here, but in between heavy grinding sessions, I forgot what was actually going on.  Overall, the game is fun and the combat is exciting, but I did get frustrated many times after getting thoroughly whooped on the battlefield (battle-space?).  Hopefully SPAZ 2 will be released soon with improved features and gameplay.PROS+ Controls are intuitive once you get used to them (WASD oriented towards mouse pointer)+ Combat is mostly fun and exciting+ Large number of ship upgrades and modules to purchase and find+ Customizing ships is fun (weapons, armor, subsystems, specialists)+ Resources (currency, data, and manpower) are plentiful+ Each star system has factions to interact with via quests and events (but...see CON)CONS- Mothership can only be upgraded after certain story missions (required for most other upgrades)- Grinding is necessary to advance- Most missions ultimately feel the same (battle after battle after battle...)- Since faction respect doesn't carry between systems, it feels rather unimportant long-term- Needs autosave function

												This game has provided me 122 hours of entertainment. Which is an absurd amount for many games of its type out right now. Granted, I never want to play it again due to both doing all there was to do (within reason) and being completely obsessive about looking at every ship, every part, and every configuration thereof. It has this weird feel about it that makes me remember the "games you can't find anymore" as the authors call it. Without actually being able to call to mind what games it refers to exactly.The art is quite unique and detailed. The character portraits are randomly generated for specialists which can generate some amusing stuff. The plot-relevant portraits are made using the same dada-style copy & paste technique that the specialists do, just not randomly generated. It's pretty charming really.

r 1, 2015
												Game goes fine until a mid-game "change" (trying to avoid spoiler). After this, the game becomes nigh unplayable IMO. The simplest of missions will involve you taking down 30+ ships.....with your 4. They do come in waves somewhat, but thats little consolation. Your reward for this slaughter, should you succeed? Not enough enough resources to rebuild a single huge ship (the largest hanger size you can field). The only other game i can think of that i've played where i hit a "wall" akin to this was Diablo 3 in torment. Maybe some hardcore people enjoy beating their head painfully against walls like this, but unless you consider yourself one of them. Dont waste the initial 20-30 hours getting to that point. Save yourself the effort and just go bash your head on the nearest doorframe.

content:
r 1, 2016
												This game really should have been called Galactic Renegade Interlopers, Nefarious Desperados, Interstellar Nasty Ghouls, as grinding is all you do.  You go to a system, see how much the local two factions feel about you, see what you can buy from the faction that likes you, chill out by a friendly mining station to get resources, see what missions you can do that don't ♥♥♥♥ off the faction that doesn't like you, go bribe the other faction so you can buy their stuff, find some way of getting more crew to replace the ones you lost bribing your new friends, and then when the system is done, either bribe some more to unlock the warp gates, or shoot your friends in the back.  Story missions are massive spikes in difficulty requiring a lot of leveling from you.  They didn't make a massive randomly generated galaxy for the fun of it, as you will be wandering around picking fights and strip-mining it to get the xp and tech needed.  Just not for me as I don't have the time.

number of helpful: 9 of 24 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2013
												I expected more of a strategy game, but the bulk of the gameplay in Space Pirates and Zombies (SPAZ) is about twitchy 2D space combat.I struggled to master the controls. I would have preferred a basic twin-stick control system, like Robotron. Instead, SPAZ features an awkward combination of using the keyboard for thrusters, and the mouse for direction and aim. The result is a game that looks like hockey pucks on an ice rink flying around, shooting wildly at each other. It's really unpleasant to play.I've played the tutorial mission through twice now, and each time I have come away wondering why I would want to continue. The gameplay is poor, and the various elements of SPAZ don't come together to make a pleasing whole. I'm underwhelmed, and happy to set this aside.

content:
0, 2014
												The worst game I ever played in my entire life. Everything is boring, nothing gets you entertained.SPAZ is a space "shooter" game and when you are used to control fast engines, in this game it's freaking slow and for the best part of the game, you're shooting lasers, because missiles are mainstream.You mostly take 10 minutes to kill a piece of sh*t with those lasers and again, when you think you're almost having fun, the ennemies are flying 20 000 km away but they won't leave the area, no, because you're having fun chasing them for nothing. In the end I got with a ship I couldn't destroy because he was escaping me anytime he's almost dying. And when he's out of my sight, he regenerates.The game has more than 100 areas to explore, all of them look the same and are infinite in length but empty of things.Each area has missions, pretty boring ones and repetitive. It also has a level system, 100 levels it seems, but totally useless because every ability you increase does no effect! It's only useful for new engine parts: lasers, shield, cloak, etc.The level can also tell you how hard an area can be. But you will always die more than 20 times before clearing one.There's plenty of ships to unlock, each ranged by class: small, medium, large, huge. You won't get something good before getting a huge ship, that means, in the end of the game when you have nothing else to do.However, mods can give a great visual but nobody gives a.. and only 2 mods are available: halloween and xmas. wow.I admit I played with a trainer but even with that it's a pain to play this horrible game.2.5/10

content:
9, 2013
												Before you ask, no, i dont have a steam copy, my copy of this game is actually non-steam (humble bundle, look it up), but this is a really cool ship combat game that i suck at.  Despite the cheesy title, this game is actually a really fun game all in all, mixing all sorts of things into the game.Storyline in a nutshell: New element, Rez, is discovered. This one government, the UTA, uses this element to make warp gates that can let ships travel to different solar systems. However, they're total warp-gate nazis and the civilians dont like it, so they get their own ships and start fighting UTA (peaceful civilians... who said that?) ships all over.Just a little background knowledge.Now, what you do is use these ships to take a side on factions... don't worry, whatever you do will only affect faction relations in the system you're in, which means you can go take down a huge UTA convoy, go to a different system, and poof! Aside from that system, nobody gives a crap! Very fun gameplay, and when it comes to taking sides, its always open for change. However, you will start at different levels of relations with factions per system, and... whatever. Just play the game already.

content:
ry 12, 2014
												If you are offended by foul language, steer clear. It isn't just enemy pilots about to die; it isn't just in dialogs with lowlifes; it is in the ambient sound for the game itself (presumably intercom chatter aboard your own vessel). Totally unnecessary, and adds no value to the game.Now, after turning the noise completely off, and ignoring the dialogs (which you can probably get away with, since the in-game indicators tell you what you need to do next), you can get around that objection, so what is left?A lot of grinding. I don't mind grinding, generally, but I appreciate some sort of appreciable reward for grinding. Admittedly, I didn't go far in the game, but the whole time I felt behind.Regrets that I can't give a positive comment. Building and maintaining a small space task force is right up my alley, so I thought it would be great. It isn't.

Some missions are fun, others just feel like BS-Also the control sceme is somewhat awkward."The bit above was my original review, i wrote it about 3 or so hours into the game.Now, having finished it after about 45hrs of playtime (that's a single playthrough, so if the game can keep you engaged, there is very good playtime value in it... Most of it was repetive/grind-ish missions however), i am somewhat torn. In the long run it was better,  than my first impression. Certainly not terrible. However, was it good enough, to change my vote? I don't think so. On a more refined scale, i would have voted differently - a 6 out of 10 perhaps. But with only "Yay" or "Nay" as possible votes, i'll stick to my initial negative vote.After all, after wrtitng that original bit, i stopped playing for a few days. Might havenever returned, but was really-really bored, so took it up again.A few nice extras came up, but my two main complaints - grind and awkward controls - remained in place.The story was ok for a open world-ish combat game, where no one really cares about story anyway. Predictable and very cliche, but enough to keep you moving from chapter to chapter. Actaully, when changing chapters there were a few interesting changes in the mechanics. Late game even had something a kin to a basic strategic layer, with defense chokepoints and ressource management - very-very-very basic, but nevertheless, an interesting change of pace.However, it did not do away with the grindy-ness. Rather the need for ressources increased. To progress the story i had to do the same missions over and over again (same objectives, slightly different maps). In the end i was just cherry-picking the missions, that i could do the fastest (cloak, destroy the target, get out).I had unlocked all the ships, all the modules about half way through the game. Picked my favorites rather quickly too. Most new unlocks i only tried for a short while (one or two fights), found them inferior, to what i already had and never used them again.Now, i am willing to believe, that there is some bit of personal prefference involved - other player might select other ships at some point. However, there is also somewhat poor balance - some ships of the same class, are clearly and stricktly superior to others - more health, more equipment slots.Bounty hunter designs in particular seem very strong - perhaps a sort of power creep in the development process.My main complaint remains the control scheme, even after 45 hours of gameplay i still wasn't fully used to it. I can't even rightly describe it - it's just not intuitive. Basically the strafe controls are pivoted on the ship, rather than on the screen. And since the ship can be spinning all willy-nilly, depending on where you aim your mouse (which is where your target is, so you can't just say "screw it" and steer with the mouse), the direction of strafing is kinda flipping around, so sometimes ushing left, will make you move left, while other times you push left, yet go right. That made strafing completely unviable for me.

												A conceptually good game that ultimately suffers from being very grindy and surprisingly difficult.  The grindy-ness is kind of just the nature of the game and if you can deal with the controls and feel immersed in the universe and enjoy the combat, you probably won't care.  Most games are repetitve after all.  But I found the universe to not be quite as interesting as advertised and the rpg-like elemnts of the game to be not bad per-se, but not really compelling or interesting either.The difficulty is at least to some degree, a by-product ofthe awkward controls.  This game needs controller support, it begs to have twin-stick controls.  Its just too hard otherwise it would be a fine little game.  A lot of people apparently adapted to the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ controls but I just couldn't as a long time Geometry Wars type player I just can't get the hang of the combat........and thats the entire game so yea.  Its slightly unfair of me to knock the game because I suck at it......but how much foresight and budget would it really have taken for them to include controller support?  Ring Runner Flight of the Sages manages it at a similar price-point and would be the game I would recommend instead.

ber 29, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game and there's quite a few things that are good about it, but it's just not nearly enough to recommend this...What is SPAZ?This game puts you in a more or less randomly generated 2D galaxy. You can set the amount of star systems, the difficulty, the tech advancements and randomize the tech tree. That's pretty much it. I've played a game with 300 systems and started one with 150. I honestly don't see the difference, which already brings me to the biggest issue I have with it:This game is utterly and truly boring. You are going to do the same thing over and over and over and over again. That is: Fly to a subsystem, complete missions to raise your standing with 1 of the 2 factions, which of course hate each other, in order to gain resources you need to (re)build ships, gather upgrade points and buy new modules like better shields, etc.There is a main mission to follow, but honestly after 10 hours of gameplay I've not been able to progress this very much, since every main mission is multiple sub systems apart. Now, you've got to understand that these subsystems have a level requirement attached to it, which means you need to break a blockade to access a new subystem. That in turn means grinding out levels to get more upgrades and fighting against superior foes either technologically speaking or just sheer numbers. The next problem with this is that you only get new and better ships by destroying these same ships multiple times first to get the blueprints. In my first playthrough I just didn't get any good ships that would even survive against the enemy for a few seconds most of the time. It doesn't help that most damage is unavoidable and your ai ships are dumb as ♥♥♥♥.In the end this means ginding, grinding, grinding...and that's not what I was looking for in a space exploration and combat game. Not to mention that after 10 hours there are still no zombies, so I can't even comment on how the gameplay changes after you reach that stage, but since I was finally able to complete another main mission, only to realize I need to grind another TEN levels to even GET to the next mission area I said "♥♥♥♥ you", as this is a bottomless pit. Even with just 150 subystems you're going to be doing this for 100 hours I feel. Not worth it, especially since the gameplay does not change at all throughout the whole game. The only difference is that you get bigger ships that move slower, but the main combat system and weapons stay the same. Pretty disappointed in this one. :/

Product received for free
												Oh, look! A game set in space where you to read tons of witty text to learn how to build ships! And it got "Zombie" in the title! Not boring or ripetitive at all! SO indie and original! I really do not like this game. Often compared to Star Control, it has neither the charm nor the entertainment of the game. It tries to imitate an old game style that died for a reason; it's not very good. The game starts off promising, shoots itself in the foot. The game is Repetitive, with a capital R, with such abysmal lack of content I don't understand how it got released in like so. You get maybe a handful of ships to play with, and the majority of them you will never use. At no point in time through playing the game did I ever concern myself with resources, as there was never any need. If you play well you're given everything you ever need. The missions feel tedious and the grinding for blueprints is aggravating, not to mention the restrictive modular system it presents. Why make such an amazing modular setup, then take it away, forcing specific pieces on the ship designs? So instead of getting a massive fleet of awesome variety, you get... cookie cutter setups. It makes the whole system feel a waste.Perhaps I am too hard on the game. It gave me 2 hours of entertainment! But afterwards, it felt so old, so repetitive

												It's been a few years since I played this, but I really did enjoy it quite a lot. The story was fun and compelling, the challenge was inviting and encuraged you to explore around for resources before progressing, but without it feeling too grindy. The Bounty Hunter update also improved many of the problems the game originally had. I'm really looking forward to SPAZ2 as well, which I know is quite a different type of game.

er 20, 2011
												Great indie title that can be approached in a variety of ways. On easier difficulties and on large planetery systems it plays like a Diablo-esque version of Beat Hazard where you grind enemies for research (xp), goons (prisoners) and REZ ($) in order to improve your fleet. On higher difficulties and smaller galaxies you need to approach things more cautiously and you'll need to plan ahead. There are many types of ships that you can unlock by reverse engineering their hulls and each ship can be upgraded with a variety of weapons (rocket launchers, turrets, lazers, drones, etc). The game offers a per-planetery system alliance mechanism, a research system involving  dozens of technologies that directly effect your ships (engine,hull,etc), a trading system, some randomized missions and events. Combat is real time but there's also a pause button/tactical screen. There's more than meets the eye in this one.

y 28, 2012
												This is a game of a style (had I the time and the talent) I have always wanted to make.  It's a very pleasant combination of genres.  The closest game I can think of that would be similar is Starscape.Shoot asteroids for resources, kill ships for xp and crew.  Defeat a new type of ship and you get their blueprint.  Get enough of that blueprint and you can build that ship.  Blast your way through blockades, or trade and bribe your way past.The loadout interface is surprisingly easy.  It's fun experimenting with different components and weapons on different hardpoints of different hulls.  Do I add a way stronger blaster and hope I don't run out of reactor power in the middle of a fight?  Do I prefer speed or maneuverability?  Cloak or shields?  Bombs, drones, torpedoes or missiles?  Tracking turrets or forward-facing sheer oomph?The middle-end of the game gets a bit grindy, but the collector/completionist in me still has plenty to do.  The developers are cool and keep adding stuff!

												This game is super addictive and fun! Well worth the money.It has an excellent simple to control combat, the difficuly on default normal is just right and I have always felt it's my own fault for not being prepared for a fight or getting in over my head when I've had to retreat. It's also very forgiving of failure, which so far has merely meant licking my wounds and spending a few minutes gathering crew and money. Sometimes by taking my rage out of weaker systems at the same time.The only time I felt I had an unfair loss (I'll skip the mission details, save to say I needed to be stealthy) and the one thing I can point out that actually needs improving is the AI ships on your team that you're not currently controlling will sometimes ignore a "passive" command and fire at enemies anyway when you're trying not to engage. I simply recycled those ships and went solo and succeeded later, then rebuilt the ships again which takes mere seconds afterward.The good number of ship selection and weapons, and the ability to place different weapons or boosters in slots give you a advantage, or occasionally disadvantage, and give a feeling of variety and tactics to the combat. If you choose poorly you needn't fear losing a mission usually, you can go into the "hanger" screen refit your ship(s) and have them warp out and a handfull of seconds later warp back into the map.It has an "rpg" element that you level up and select to upgrade over a dozen types of parts of your ship to work better and be able to equip new things which further gives you a feeling of being in control of your ships.The visuals are very beautiful and colorfull eye candy, but you can see all that in the pictures or youtube vids.

The graphics are very pleasing especially for a cartoon look. The sound fit's the game well as does the artwork. SPAZ has several difficulty settings ranging from "casual just play for fun and never lose" to "please just kill me now". On it's most difficult setting even the most experienced gamers will be tested. The galaxy can be created relatively small (still very large offering many hours of gameplay) to massive offering literally hundreds of hours of play time. The map is also randomly generated so replay value is high. Bounty Hunters (free DLC) adds a fourth faction to interact with adding new ways to explore or destroy star systems!All in all a highly suggested purchase that will offer something to all gamers, casual and hardcore alike.

												On the surface, this may just look like Asteroids 2011. And yes, the 2D space battles are awesome and the control mechanics are good once you're used to them. But it's  also part RPG: your ships as your characters, complete with loadouts, unlocks, and even skills via your tech research.  And part RTS, via a rudimentary tactical screen where you can control your forces mid-battle. You unlock new ships by destroying someone else's model - even your allies' - and scouring  the wreckage; piracy comes naturally in the game. Cuz hey... that's a beautiful new ship your "valued comrade" just brought to battle. It'd be a shame if anything happened to it...

ber 11, 2012
												This was a pleasant surprise of a space sim, in which the focus is as much on the 2D top-down space combat as it is on resource collection, faction negotiation/manipulation, and technology collection. It has a very RPG feel - as you gain experience and level, you place points into the systems of your ship that you most rely on, forcing you to always evaluate your strategy as there are MANY different systems to put points into, and the ships that you receive all use them differently. I did not expect to get sucked into this game, nor did I expect it to last as long as it did. Be careful with this one - it can get addictive very quickly. And once you get going, it's going to carry you a lot longer than you'll expect. It does get too repetitive towards the end of the game, and a lot of that time was spent grinding out materials. 3 out of 5 foxes.

ber 20, 2014
												I've played all 3 Escape Velocity games, if that is what these guys were trying to emulate they failed.This game is overly complicated from the beginning, it has a difficulty curve like a mountain and has combat that simply doesn't have a good feel to it, which is important as there isn't much more to this game.  There is a plot, some narration, but honestly the level of the dialouge and the amateur art designs for the charcacters caused me to ignore it after about 10 minutes.This is Diablo in space, you manuever around, try to damage opponents and mostly are just trying to click at the right times to line up shots against VERY agile opponents.   You also constantly have to keep track of how allies are doing, your ship is usually worse then your competitions and there are more of them then there are of your fleet (as opposed to most ARPGs where you have an advantage but you are facing a horde).  It is very easy to die but that's ok, because using your mined resources you can then use them to respawn yourself and your fleet.  But you can and will run out of resources, therefore making you not be able to respawn, at which point the game tells you to go get in a very very very crappy ship and start mining, but anyone with common sense will tell you to reload your save instead to save you the mindless grinding that would entail.This is grossly dissapointing because I feel there is a lot to this game, it generates a new galaxy for every game which would seem to have a huge amount of content but I couldn't get past the second star system and had great difficulty getting past the first (which was the tutorial).  Maybe this game was made for the nintendo hard crowd, or maybe I just suck, but I just don't have the time or patience anymore to deal with that.  Although after looking at the universal badge progress on this game, I can tell I'm not alone.Don't trust the metacritic score, although I will say there is something here but you have to be pretty dedicated/skilled to find it.

er 23, 2016
												SPAZ, the space sim with an attitude. Having none other than TotalBiscuit himself as the narrator, it's one of the best hidden gems among space games, with a great story, insane unforgiving but very rewarding gameplay, infinite replayability and a style, that no other game can match. A very detailed universe with it's own history and unique characters, blending all that is nerd (Space, Pirates and Zombies, obviously. No Ninjas though...). What it lacks in visuals, makes up for tenfold in fun.Highly recommended!

er 26, 2016
												What a game, what a work of art for a two-person team.It's so beautiful, from the debris-strewn starscapes to the twinkling spaceships and spinning starbases. The sound effects are good, too. The background chatter could have used more variety, but it was so well done and unobstrusive that it never annoyed me. The misanthropic humor is pervasive throughout the game, from the main characters' dialogue to the way slavery is tacitly endorsed by everyone.There are lots intriguing ships, weapons, and upgrades to try, though brute-force lasering was how I usually settled things. The beams-cannons-missiles damage system makes you carefully weigh your strengths and weaknesses, while the rez-goons-data economy keeps you hunting for ways to exploit and score. I would have liked more missions and factions, though.The difficulty of the game is quite well balanced until the very end. I got stuck many times, but getting unstuck often required just a different fleet or loadout. And when I needed a break, I could look for other things to do like collect components or free up warp gates.Still, the game is undeniably a grind. With there being only two factions and not much in the way of plot and missions, there is a lot of looking for other things to do. When the game got too repetitive, I'd play it intensely for a few weeks and then stop for a few months before playing again.What bothers me most is how the game ended. In the last chapter, I did the minimum I had to do to proceed to the finale. I then saved the game and went ahead to the finale just to take a brief peek at it, expecting to be defeated right away. Fifteen minutes later, I'd won the game without breaking a sweat. That was really disappointing. I was playing on Normal difficulty with a tech level of 113, so I don't think I was overleveled. In fact, the unique side missions were still very tough for me. Even the story, which I found fairly interesting, ended flatly.

er 20, 2011
												Great indie title that can be approached in a variety of ways. On easier difficulties and on large planetery systems it plays like a Diablo-esque version of Beat Hazard where you grind enemies for research (xp), goons (prisoners) and REZ ($) in order to improve your fleet. On higher difficulties and smaller galaxies you need to approach things more cautiously and you'll need to plan ahead. There are many types of ships that you can unlock by reverse engineering their hulls and each ship can be upgraded with a variety of weapons (rocket launchers, turrets, lazers, drones, etc). The game offers a per-planetery system alliance mechanism, a research system involving  dozens of technologies that directly effect your ships (engine,hull,etc), a trading system, some randomized missions and events. Combat is real time but there's also a pause button/tactical screen. There's more than meets the eye in this one.

This was with standard difficulty and standard size of the galaxy. Having said that, i did not even explore everything even with those amount of hours played.For people who want a different pace, and a game in which they can pick up and play from time to time. Then i can highly recommend SPAZ. It's fun, addictive at times, and it's also very easy to pick up even after not having played it for 2 weeks.

												I was looking for a modern classic-style top-down space exploration game with modifiable ships and asteroid mining but all I could find was a bunch of pay-to-win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like Dark Orbit. Then I stumbled on SPAZ and honestly it's everything I wanted and more. It's open-world but structured so you don't get overwhelmed by the vastness of space. I'm very impressed with how refined and balanced the experience is. Everything from upgrades, fighting, and leveling up has had a lot of thought put into it. This does not feel like a 2-person studio production, it plays like a passion project from a very skilled game studio. I've played 20 hours so far, which is saying something considering most of the games in my library are barely touched regardless of their rating, and can't wait until I have time to play it more. I'm looking forward to playing more of this game and cannot wait until SPAZ 2!

y 21, 2016
												This game fulfilled my dream of becoming a space pirate. The controls are engaging, the world convincing, the physics satisfying (ship explosions!), the story amusing, the space battles epic, and the graphics pleasing to the eye. Downsides are: the world is immense, but largely homogeneous - the gameplay becomes repetitive after a time. In the challenging systems, if you take a hard hit in a battle, it can take a while to recoup your lost resources. The ship and fleet customization is enjoyable, but there are only a couple missions that require particular kinds of builds. All in all, lot's of great fun to be had for the space pirate at heart, or the person that doesn't yet know they're a space pirate.

r 17, 2015
												SPAZ is a great space-combat game. I haven't played a space game this fun since Escape Velocity: Nova. If the 2D space genre at all interests you, you need to buy it, now. Fans of this game should also take a look at Drox Operative, which takes a more Diablo-esque stance to space combat, though I find that controls in that game to be less fun.This game, though fun, lacks a fair amount of depth. it has it's problems, and I shall list some of those out here. Make no mistake, my overall rating for this game would still be an 8/10.First of all, alt+tabbing is a bit of a pain. You need an active window to tab into otherwise it won't work.The intro movies, though short, are not skippable.Skipping the tutorial leaves you at a bit of a disadvantage level wise.I cannot figure out enemy aggro. Sometimes, they choose to target exclusively my own ships despite other enemy ships attacking them.On a mission to kill enemy scouts, if the scouts are friendly, it is impossible because my own ships will not target them.I cannot select enemy ships to be targeted from the tactical menu. Targeting specific enemy ships can be a pain sometimes and this would help immensely.Enemy ships will often only attack my escorts. And my escorts will fly way off to attack enemy ships. This has led to all my rez being depleted while I just sit there and do nothing.More AI options are needed. Even defensive AI is way too aggressive. An AI option where friendly ships never leave the screen would be nice.Better yet, formations would be a welcome addition to the game. Even just one basic formation would be extremely helpful in keeping my fleet in line.Friendly AI ships get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off way too easily.There aren't enough missions to weaken the enemy faction in a given system. This forces me to either attack a level 3 space station, or make peace with the enemy at the expense of my ally.As a final sidenote, I love the radio chatter that goes on. You should allow people to upload their own chatter for inclusion into the game somehow.

												10/10 Very addictive game.  I played about 1 hour of this game 18 months ago then came back and started a new game 2 weeks ago.  It took me 80 hrs to complete a new game.  The addictive part of the game is chasing the next upgrade, blueprint or skill levelup.   I recomend game saving alot early-mid game.  The game was very challenging till, Hammerhead ship dropped toward the middle of chapter 3. The game became super easy after getting max level cannons and Mammath during chapter 4.  Mammath is OP with triple mount Partical Cannons, double mount Mass Drivers, and Battle Station.   This game reminds me of a 100x more advanced version of Asteroids, that I played hundreds of times in the mid-80s at the YMCA.  The game has a good story and great 2d graphics.  Another similarly enjoyable game to try is Reassembly.

ry 11, 2013
												For a 2-man indie development team, one would not think that SPAZ could amount to much. Anyone thinking this: Boy were you wrong. SPAZ is a top-down, 2-D space-based shooter that combine RPG, RTS and some two-point elements to combine into a great, trully awesome game.At the time of writing this I have not beat it yet, but I have however sunk over 70 hours into it and really enjoyed myself. The game provides a plot and a purpose to strive for, but you get to chose how you get there. What ships you use, how you equip them, what tactics you employ, where you go, who you befriend/betray/fight, it's all up to you.If you enjoy Sci-Fi and shooters and a simple but great game with a rather twisted, grim-dark universe, all for the low price of 9 EURO's that don't demand a monster of a gaming PC, this is for you.

												This game is 90% great and 10% rubbish.  Its great when everything is going smoothly and you're rampaging around the galaxy killing stuff and its terrible when you get a certain map with an AI ship (in one of the fastest ships in the game) that shoots at you for a bit then runs off when it is near death, then comes back and shoots you again before running off.  When you have done this for 10 mins straight you will hate this game as much as I do - however, with a bit of patience you will realise that you can re-fit your ships mid-match to allow you to catch the tricky bugger or use drones which are faster than most ships.  .

Also if  you need resources it's kind of a grind to accumulate them.  And the upgrade system kind of keeps you locked with regard to what weapons you use.  Switching to a different weapon type costs you all of the upgrade bonuses which typically doesn't work.Saving the game: If you get invaded when going to the mothership to save, you could be forced to fight another 10-15 minutes of ships and reinforcements before you can save the game. er 29, 2011
												Space Pirats and Zombies is a fantastic achievement in of itself.  Its in the same vein as the old Star Control games in that it features an entirely "Top Down" perspective space combat experience. Despite what may seem like a straight forward simple game at first glance will quickly be washed away by how massive the galaxy can be if you so choose.SPAZ sports an intuitive levelling system where you earn points to spend on research to boost the attributes of several systems of your ships. From shields to turrets to the crew itself, the inner workings of your vessels will be fine tuned as you grow. Where you choose to research also determines what higher quality systems you will be able to implement as you acquire various blueprints for more efficient arms and armors. I would highly recommend this game to any and all who enjoy space combat. Its very action packed and exciting, at least in my opinion.It is truly the triumph of a motivated two man development team!

												I was looking for a modern classic-style top-down space exploration game with modifiable ships and asteroid mining but all I could find was a bunch of pay-to-win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like Dark Orbit. Then I stumbled on SPAZ and honestly it's everything I wanted and more. It's open-world but structured so you don't get overwhelmed by the vastness of space. I'm very impressed with how refined and balanced the experience is. Everything from upgrades, fighting, and leveling up has had a lot of thought put into it. This does not feel like a 2-person studio production, it plays like a passion project from a very skilled game studio. I've played 20 hours so far, which is saying something considering most of the games in my library are barely touched regardless of their rating, and can't wait until I have time to play it more. I'm looking forward to playing more of this game and cannot wait until SPAZ 2!

, 2015
												S.P.A.Z (Space Pirates and Zombies) is a top down arcade, tactical space battle simulator/ RPG.I did little proof reading of this review, it took a while to write and I’m not up to the task atmTo nail some key points,Good - The ships are very well done in design (both balancing and stylistic) but get a bit blurry when zoomed in fully (especially noticeable with the largest class of ship).  - The map is random generated along with most of side missions - The actually "arenas" or player maps where your battles take place look very well done but may get little generic over time although not that noticeable - All the weapons and subsystem special effects are very well done for the top down look - Weapon balancing is a kinda weird at times and falls down into what you prefer / best for the situation - Cookie Famous "Total Biscuit" voice acts the story transitions within this game  - Stupid space humor both live and embed within missions + the story - THE PERFECT GAME for listening to all your music in a very long playlist (be sure to set it for you still can hear the sounds effects and the space humor I mention earlier>Side Note: I will give u music to listen to if your playlist is lacking in contentMixed - You control 1 ship and the rest are set on a the default AI autopilot unless you change how they would react to you and enemies via the tactics menu BUT you can jump freely between ships at any time at a press of a button^ going with this the AI settings in my experience DO NOT remain set when change and switch to the default most prefer mode after each battle/map/mission   (I assume this is to keep you from making a mistake while in battle, but there is no way to lock it. - Zombies do not come until mid game - This game has allot of playtime and becomes a grind Bad - Due to the nature of OpenGL if you tab out of the game while loading assets will be misplaced within the game and looks very distorted unless you restart the game entirelyNow for the giant section no-one I know reads (these review are set to friends only to prevent myself from being barraged with people telling me ♥♥♥♥ instead of writing their own opinion)  WHERE IT WENT?!!---->http://puu.sh/i5zkd/2917c27b3f.txtI somehow passsed the review character limit so this is my bypassConclusion: Get this game if you’re into the whole Space combat dealio but be warn at the length of this game can become unbearable at times. Other than that it’s a good game with a sequel underway

												Edit: 1/10/2016   This game is still a blast to play. Get it and look forward to SPAZ 2!----First things first, one of the devs of this game gave away a bunch of keys for free on Reddit. Instead, I purchased the game since it was available for $3.99 as a weekend deal. I sat down with it once it downloaded, poured me a spot of Scotch, and started playing. Seven hours (!) later I realize that it was now quite early in the morning and I still found myself thinking "Just one more mission". This is easily one of the most satisfying Indie games in my library. Addicting, colorful, witty, and overall killer experience.I suggest picking this up at any price, a stellar title with some down-to-earth developers.

												The universe you know of is endangered by some unknown biological threat.As a military recruit you are set out to investigate this. Along the way all is not what it seems to be.I had a lot of fun with this one:- Beautiful colorful graphics & some nice space (contamination) effects- Believable space environments & sounds- Fleet, vessel, weapons & systems customization- Fun & sometimes hard battles, depending on your system & mission selection- Side with the military, the rebels or the pirates per system you are in- Get a bounty your head by the Bounty Hunters & fight them off to get some special ship plans or systems upgrades- Fight in the Bounty Hunters arena- Zombies in space - avoid infection!- Various but at the same time same-ish missions to choose from- Some experience grinding is required to reach your goals- Thus be prepared to waste a lot of time to finish it- Weak & easy ending. Some mid-level missions were much, much harderMakes me curious for SPAZ2.<Offline mode - so don't get fooled by steams low "hrs on record">

y 7, 2015
												SPAZ is a top-down space grinder. You start with almost nothing and build your way up to the commander of a squad of ships. As you complete story missions, you gain access to larger hangars which means larger ships to command. You can manipulate your enemies and scavange their ships after they've destroyed one another. You can eradicate infections and undermine the local rebellion or authority figures. Pros-Fun! Collecting the various weapons and tools, then customized your ships to find the best combinations is hours of enjoyment.Unique! Not many games I've played have the variety of units and unpredictability of SPAZ. I've seen ships that shouldn't have succeeded destroy others that are twice their size.Cons-Wash, Rinse, Repeat- A bit repetitive at times. Requires lots of time grinding to find the blueprints for all the ships. Not always the most fun, but it DOES make getting your first HUGE ship so rewarding.Angry? Have some Goons- Very easy to manipulate the factions by bribing them with goons (a sort of influence currency). Once you're on their good sides, you can just wait for them to butt heads and collect the cash, goons, data, and blueprints left over from their conflicts. Not super challenging.Braaaaaaains- The Zombies are very unique and sometimes absurdly over powered. Still need to get used to them, but their initial strategies require you to change your thinking ALOT.9/10 BUY IT (ESPECIALLY IF IT'S ON SALE)
